Description: Scarab in glazed composition, probably mould-made; underside decorated with half a cartouche to right, containing three debased hieroglyphic signs, while left side completely damaged; green glaze (according to the initial G on Petrie's drawing).
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 76). Petrie illustrated variants of this association of an animal - often a falcon or a mythical creature - with a debased hieroglyphic inscription (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 71-78). Such compositions are common on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B1-12). The hieroglyphs in the "half cartouche", as seen in many similar examples, are often interpreted as a debased version of pharaohs' names (Gorton 1996, 93). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 76)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.058) (phase 3)
